page.title: 11HOUSING IN NORTH HUISH
page.content: High wages and mechanisation have led to decline in population of agricultural workers. Many of their cottages have disappeared, while others are inhabited by commuting workers in nearby towns. Apart from barn conversions the only new building is a bungalow on the site of Ivy Cottage and the{Village School,}closed in 1919. Several farms have historic connections; two of these, on the { {VENN ESTATE,} were once a single farm. Lower Well, built of half stone and half cob, covers 63 acres. Higher Well was converted from a barn, and owned by the same family since 1904. It is of stone with slate roof, and let out annually as grass keep. There is the remains of a pit used until 1900 for cockfighting, now illegal.Fowelscombe 243 acres owned by one family since 1300.One ancestor fought for{Cromwell.
